summary:
The story of the Night’s King is trying to tell us something about Jon and Bran. 
A Lord Commander of the Night’s Watch takes up...
body:
The story of the Night’s King is trying to tell us something about Jon and Bran.

A Lord Commander of the Night’s Watch takes up with an ice priestess. His King Stark brother joins with the King Beyond the Wall to defeat him.

We have a Lord Commander (Jon), a fire priestesses (Melisandre), a Stark king (Bran as Robb’s heir), and a very recent King Beyond the Wall with wildlings in the mix.

I just can’t sort out what the correct formula here is.

Does Melisandre resurrect Jon and they become the Night’s King and his bride? Does Dany take the place of his bride? It makes most sense for Jon to be the Night’s King in this equation, but he could also fit into the other two positions with a little work.

Is Bran the King of Winter? Or does he fall into the place of the King Beyond the Wall (with the Others/CotF in the place of wildlings?)? Just remember, Joramun later broke his strength attacking the Wall and Winterfell.

And who does this leave for the last place. If we are looking for a King of Winter Sansa and Arya fit the position. We are short King’s Beyond the Wall, Stannis or Dany? Perhaps Val or Tormund?

If Jon is the Night’s King and Bran the King Beyond the Wall, then Jon is going to do something dark and related to magic. Perhaps the Others aren’t evil, and Jon tries to convince everyone else of this and they don’t believe him? Or perhaps he gets into Mel’s shadowbinding (and the Others aren’t evil?). Then Bran and the Stark in Winterfell have to kill Jon. And then, to top it off, Bran attacks the south with an army and fails.

Likewise, if Bran is the Stark in this case, he has to kill both Jon and destroy the King Beyond the Wall.

There’s also an option for Bran to be the Night’s King with a less-literal “bride” in an Other or CotF.

summary:
do you ever just think about how young all the main protagonists of GoT were in the books and they went through so much 
In the...
body:
do you ever just think about how young all the main protagonists of GoT were in the books and they went through so much

In the novel(s) I’m pretty sure like 2-3 years passes between all the novels but I could be wrong, please correct me if I am:

Daenerys: 13-15 (is abused by her brother, marries Khal Drogo (who is in his early 30s), is r*ped by him, and gives birth to Rhaego when she’s 14 (which is how old my mother was when she gave birth to my oldest brother) and it really is just gross @ GRRM what were you thinking. Is sexually assaulted by Jorah Mormont, a much older man, who she trusts and views as a friend, and much, much more)

Jon: 14-16 (his relationship w/Ygritte in the books really irks me considering she’s 17/18 and if the Jon were a woman and Ygritte were man it would be considered super sketch but whatever, takes on the job of Lord Commander when he’s like 16)

Robb: 14-16 (goes to war, kills men at 14 because of Joffrey betrayal of his father, has the burden of kingship places upon him, is around 16 when he dies)

Sansa: 11-13 (12(?) when she is forced to marry Tyrion, though he doesn’t force her to do anything (he still thinks about her sexually), is essentially groomed by LF, beaten and abused in front of the whole court, emotionally abused by Cersei, lives w/the guilt of having been forced by the Lannisters to essentially betray her father, has her beloved pet murdered for something she didn’t do, etc.)

Arya: 9-11 (witnessed her father being beheaded, is later turned into an assassin by a super shady group of people, has her friend murdered by the Lannisters, finds a family in Gendry only to have that taken away, is seperated from her family, etc.)

Bran: 7-9 (is pushed from a window and permenantly disabled, is forced from his home + separated from his family)

Rickon: 2-4 (forced to flee Winterfell because it’s taken over and is separated from his whole family)

Theon Greyjoy: 18/19(?)-20/21 (is castrated/tortured by Ramsay Bolton until he loses all sense of who he is)

Brienne of Tarth: 17-19 (witnesses the death of her king (who she is in love with), and is forced to take on various missions in a bid to fulfill her promise to Catelyn Stark)

Now I may be wrong by like a year or two for some of them but still. They’re all so young. Also I couldn’t list everything each other’s characters went though bc I’ve just began rereading the first book and I don’t remember that much from the series. If you have anything to add feel free because I no doubt missed quite a few things/if I got anything wrong.

summary: This is going to be kind of spoilerish .... so don’t read if you don’t want to be kind of spoiled (but honestly, this is...
body:
8x01 REUNIONS

This is going to be kind of spoilerish …. so don’t read if you don’t want to be kind of spoiled (but honestly, this is obviously something you already know is going to happen lol)


WARNING: SPOILER - ISH


➖➖➖➖➖➖➖➖➖➖➖➖


While I’m excited for many reunions to take place this season, I’m very interested in how the Theon & Bran reunion will go. We know from spoilers that Theon is heading North.


Theon (I still love him, Alfie’s portrayal is so damn good, even when the writing fails him) really hurt and betrayed the Starks, especially a young Bran. He killed Ser Rodrick and he planned to kill Bran & Rickon.

When Bran asked Theon “Did you hate us the whole time” that moment killed me 😭 the way he said it just broke my heart.

*not my gif*



Bran is the 3ER, he knows how much Theon has suffered since his betrayal, he also knows that Theon helped Sansa escape Ramsay.


It’s been said that Bran won’t be as robotic this season, he’ll show more emotion, I’m looking forward to his reaction to Theon being back at WF.

blog.description:
Daenerys was my first fave and she will be my last.

Danielle, US. Meera is the frog queen of my heart but I post more about my dragon queen Dany. Trying to be a happy person against the will of all these nihilistic men.

This is my ASOIAF/GOT side blog. My main is a-mountain-girl, my booklr is readingaway.

summary: What do you think Bran's storyline will be this season? Like do you think we might get our old Bran back?
question: What do you think Bran's storyline will be this season? Like do you think we might get our old Bran back?
answer:
Lol I wish we’d get the real Bran back. I have no idea what he’s going to be doing because he’s got these amazing magical skills and those have to be essential to defeating the WW BUT the production doesn’t appear to get that. Or care. Because so far they’ve literally just used him for flashbacks (and there’s fans trying to construe that this is because R+L=J must be like essential to the endgame when it’s really not it’s just something D&D fixate on and for whatever reason they didn’t want Bran doing his own thing, maybe it had to do with the budget or it would add “too much confusion”). The scene when he’s shown the apparent origins of the NK is literally the only time they’ve gotten close to his real mission. I believe they’ll throw in something for him to do magically during the battle but it’s not going to make a ton of sense or be as important as whatever book!bran is going to do. But mostly he’ll be relegated to the background and only brought forward to talk about R+L or to creep someone out. Isaac has said he’ll be a little more of a person this year but I 1) don’t trust Isaac, 2) don’t trust the show (ex he could have been in a bunch of humanizing and interesting scenes that will have been cut like that one time he was plot relevant last season that got cut).

I know I’m being a pessimist but this is the only way I can deal with the show.

Thanks for talking to me!

summary: Bran, the Reeds, Hodor, and Summer do not get enough credit for their mission. While everyone else was running from the threat,...
body: Bran, the Reeds, Hodor, and Summer do not get enough credit for their mission. While everyone else was running from the threat, they were running towards it. You guys keep going on about the “suicide squad” and Dany swooping in with her dragons. No one talks about a cripple, a half giant who carries around said cripple, a direwolf, and two young and wise kids who are not accustomed to the cold, harsh weather of the real North. No dragons, no fighting experience (except for Meera, which isn’t much compared to the seasoned warriors of the “suicide squad”.) This is only one reason why Bran’s storyline is my absolute favorite. I don’t understand why people find it boring.

summary: Now because the females characters don't support d*nny her stans are moving out to B*ran.
question: Now because the females characters don't support d*nny her stans are moving out to B*ran.
answer: While I haven’t seen this myself, if that’s true, that’s quite grand of them. Weren’t they the ones who tried diminishing Bran’s importance to the story, and constantly perpetuated the notion that it was Daenerys and her dragons who were going to be the key to defeating the Night King? Speaking about Bran, I do hope that that by the end of the season, he becomes at the very least a little bit more human, and I’m certainly excited to see what exactly is going to be his role in the denouement of the story.

summary: To go South - chapter 48 - Playing cyvasse
title: To go South - chapter 48 - Playing cyvasse
body:
So, here is another chapter on the battle at Winterfell. Bran’s PoV. We do not catch up yet to the end of the Da€nerys’ chapter, but we’ll reach that at the end of the next chapter. Also on AO3.

Bran could hear their voices all the time now. It made it difficult to concentrate on what people said. The voices of the children drowned everything out. Their voices were the pulse of the earth in autumn, a slight breeze in summer, the steady dropping of a spring rain. They were insistent, urging him. He concentrated on the plan to trap the White Walkers. He dared not think beyond that. They did not understand that he would think about his family, not when they were so close to the thin veil that separated them from the access to their magic. He could hide his thoughts behind his worry for his family. In a way it was an advantage that they were all in danger.

He didn’t need to touch the weirwood any longer, and it would be a risk anyway. Bran doubted he could hide anything from them if he opened his thoughts again to the weirwood. He had not even dared to take the arrows from the tree. The children had reached out and hid Bran and Theon from the White Walkers. The enemy would not sense them, not as long as there was a feast of living souls they could expect to drain as soon as they had won the castle.

Bran let his mind wander, seeing, but not acting. The time for action would come later, for now the pieces were all set. He wondered if his siblings would think him cold. A part of him knew that they would not appreciate to be moved like pieces on a cyvasse board, but that was as far as his understanding went. He knew that they probably would be angry with him, but he did not feel it, nor did he dread their hurt.

Brienne and Jaime were fighting in a steady and constant rhythm, as if they were one person, sensing the other’s weakness, raising their swords to help the other.

Arya was a small whirlwind. Needle was everywhere, and although Gendry and her did not complement each other as well as Brienne and Jaime, they easily held their own. Bran saw the Unsullied edging closer to Gendry, the fighting was thick, but this was up to Arya.

Theon’s touch brought him back into his own body.

“Bran,” he said. “I thought about this. I don’t claim to understand everything, but I do think there is a flaw in your argument. You say it is all about balance, but if we can restore balance by destroying the White Walkers with wildfire and then killing the dragons, why can’t we do it, the other way round? Kill the dragons and then the fire magic is gone, and then White Walkers will die as well.”

Bran shook his head. We could have done that, if Daenerys had let us. But she would not give up her dragons. He would have to come up with something that would appease Theon and the voices in his head.

“If the White Walkers are killed first, the Children regain their strength and only then the arrows will be strong enough to kill the dragons. It is crucial that the scales first tip in favour of fire. It is the ice magic that channels the strength away from the Children.”

The voices in his head were satisfied. Bran could feel their pressure in his head lessen for a moment, and he heard something that felt like the far away echo of a chuckle. Quickly, he distracted himself from the sound. It would be no good if they realised that he knew they were manipulating him.

“I’ll tell you when to act. I just have to check on Jon.”

Before he concentrated on the battle again, he saw worry cast a shadow on Theon’s face. He knew he probably looked creepy when he delved into his visions, but that was not to be helped.

Bran checked on Rhaegal. It was interesting how the wall of earth magic he and Jon had built around his mind had changed the dragon. His contained fire was less dangerous, more focussed than Drogon’s, but it was still fire. Fire made flesh. Bran briefly touched Jon’s mind reassuringly. He wondered if he should have told his cousin to not grow too attached to the beast.

Sansa was leading the everybody down into the crypts. Bran could feel the tiny, tiny fleck of a being close to her heart, and he brushed his nephew ever so lightly. Olyvar Frey was at Sansa’s side, his eyes restive and Ghost flanked her on the other side. Bran could feel that Sansa was frightened, but he was sure nobody would realise that. She calmly managed the constant stream of people.

It was time now. The enemy was closing in, claiming the castle. Bran knew that there was no chance he could close of the crypts with everybody on the inside.

Arya and Gendry were at the rearguard. They might be cut off.

He knew he should be sad about this, but he had no tears. Maybe I will have tears later, when this is all over. That was a dangerous thought, he could feel the resentment and lack of understanding from the Children about his yearning for tears. He stamped on his worry for Arya. He had seen that she had a decent chance of survival after all.

Sansa led the living deeper and deeper into the tunnels. Brienne and Jaime were at the end of the column. Tyrion chose this moment to finally unburden his conscience. He had been in the middle of the column, but now he ran back and looked for his brother, his stride was unsteady. He must have drunk many tankards to be that affected.

“Jaime,” he called, “Jaime.”

His brother barely managed to save him from being killed by a White Walker when he buried his Valyrian sword in the White Walker mere moments before he touched Tyrion.

“What are you doing here?”

Bran waited. He should call the Kings of Winter now and he could feel the Children pressuring him. He stood his ground.

I don’t want them to die. I don’t want anyone to die. Go, now, leave this room, he tried to tell them.

“Sansa, I think she is in danger.” Tyrion blurted out. There were tears in his eyes. “I should have told you earlier. I think Daenerys might have bribed someone to kill her.”

Jaime pushed his brother. “Get yourself to safety. And don’t you worry. Olyvar is with Sansa.”

“But he must be the one she bribed. She said something about ‘Once a traitor always a traitor’.”

Brienne barked a laugh. “As if Olyvar would betray the woman who saved him. Believe me, Sansa is safe with him. He told us all about it and he played along.”

Bran pressed a hand to his head. The pressure was getting worse.

Tyrion looked at Brienne, understanding dawning on him. “You knew?”

“I am the Commander of the Queensguard, of course I knew.”

Jaime pushed his brother again. “Now, please, look after yourself. I have to fight.”

Wights were coming at them, but Tyrion did not see them. Maybe he was too drunk.

“Jaime,” Tyrion wailed. “I failed you. You protected King’s Landing, but I did not manage to do what you did. King’s Landing is gone and so is Cersei.”

Brienne cursed. “Why did you choose this moment to burst out with that!”

She was swinging her sword right and left, but her easy rhythm was gone. Jaime skipped a beat and Brienne barely managed to keep him from getting butchered.

“I suspected as much, Tyrion, and now, by all the Gods, get your arse out of here.”

Bran would have to risk it. Tyrion had distracted him, the chance for him running back had not been that high, and he had lost contact to Arya. He hoped that she was deeper in the crypts. He called upon the Kings of Winter like he had already done once before. He was in awe that it was so much easier now, he felt the strength of Winterfell’s magic deep in his bones. The Children were satisfied.

The statues moved and protected the crypts to where the living had fled.

Bran opened his eyes and looked at the sky that was tinged with a silver lining that forebode the dawn. A time of change, this was the right moment, between night and day, time for decisions.

“They’ll spring the trap now,” he told Theon.

His contained fire was less dangerous, more focussed than Drogon’s, but it was still fire. Fire made flesh. Bran briefly touched Jon’s mind reassuringly. He wondered if he should have told his cousin to not grow too attached to the beast.

Sansa was leading the everybody down into the crypts. Bran could feel the tiny, tiny fleck of a being close to her heart, and he brushed his nephew ever so lightly. Olyvar Frey was at Sansa’s side, his eyes restive and Ghost flanked her on the other side. Bran could feel that Sansa was frightened, but he was sure nobody would realise that. She calmly managed the constant stream of people.

It was time now. The enemy was closing in, claiming the castle. Bran knew that there was no chance he could close of the crypts with everybody on the inside.

Arya and Gendry were at the rearguard. They might be cut off.

He knew he should be sad about this, but he had no tears. Maybe I will have tears later, when this is all over. That was a dangerous thought, he could feel the resentment and lack of understanding from the Children about his yearning for tears. He stamped on his worry for Arya. He had seen that she had a decent chance of survival after all.

Sansa led the living deeper and deeper into the tunnels. Brienne and Jaime were at the end of the column. Tyrion chose this moment to finally unburden his conscience. He had been in the middle of the column, but now he ran back and looked for his brother, his stride was unsteady. He must have drunk many tankards to be that affected.

“Jaime,” he called, “Jaime.”

His brother barely managed to save him from being killed by a White Walker when he buried his Valyrian sword in the White Walker mere moments before he touched Tyrion.

“What are you doing here?”

Bran waited. He should call the Kings of Winter now and he could feel the Children pressuring him. He stood his ground.

I don’t want them to die. I don’t want anyone to die. Go, now, leave this room, he tried to tell them.

“Sansa, I think she is in danger.” Tyrion blurted out. There were tears in his eyes. “I should have told you earlier. I think Daenerys might have bribed someone to kill her.”

Jaime pushed his brother. “Get yourself to safety. And don’t you worry. Olyvar is with Sansa.”

“But he must be the one she bribed. She said something about ‘Once a traitor always a traitor’.”

Brienne barked a laugh. “As if Olyvar would betray the woman who saved him. Believe me, Sansa is safe with him. He told us all about it and he played along.”

Bran pressed a hand to his head. The pressure was getting worse.

Tyrion looked at Brienne, understanding dawning on him. “You knew?”

“I am the Commander of the Queensguard, of course I knew.”

Jaime pushed his brother again. “Now, please, look after yourself. I have to fight.”

Wights were coming at them, but Tyrion did not see them. Maybe he was too drunk.

“Jaime,” Tyrion wailed. “I failed you. You protected King’s Landing, but I did not manage to do what you did. King’s Landing is gone and so is Cersei.”

Brienne cursed. “Why did you choose this moment to burst out with that!”

She was swinging her sword right and left, but her easy rhythm was gone. Jaime skipped a beat and Brienne barely managed to keep him from getting butchered.

“I suspected as much, Tyrion, and now, by all the Gods, get your arse out of here.”

Bran would have to risk it. Tyrion had distracted him, the chance for him running back had not been that high, and he had lost contact to Arya. He hoped that she was deeper in the crypts. He called upon the Kings of Winter like he had already done once before. He was in awe that it was so much easier now, he felt the strength of Winterfell’s magic deep in his bones. The Children were satisfied.

The statues moved and protected the crypts to where the living had fled.

Bran opened his eyes and looked at the sky that was tinged with a silver lining that forebode the dawn. A time of change, this was the right moment, between night and day, time for decisions.

“They’ll spring the trap now,” he told Theon.
trail.content:

He concentrated on the plan to trap the White Walkers. He dared not think beyond that. They did not understand that he would think about his family, not when they were so close to the thin veil that separated them from the access to their magic. He could hide his thoughts behind his worry for his family. In a way it was an advantage that they were all in danger.

He didn’t need to touch the weirwood any longer, and it would be a risk anyway. Bran doubted he could hide anything from them if he opened his thoughts again to the weirwood. He had not even dared to take the arrows from the tree. The children had reached out and hid Bran and Theon from the White Walkers. He knew that they probably would be angry with him, but he did not feel it, nor did he dread their hurt.

Brienne and Jaime were fighting in a steady and constant rhythm, as if they were one person, sensing the other’s weakness, raising their swords to help the other.

Arya was a small whirlwind. Needle was everywhere, and although Gendry and her did not complement each other as well as Brienne and Jaime, they easily held their own. Bran saw the Unsullied edging closer to Gendry, the fighting was thick, but this was up to Arya.

Crazy GoT theory:
What you wanna bet Arya cuts Bran's throat with the dagger meant to kill him in the first season, which he...
body:
Crazy GoT theory:

What you wanna bet Arya cuts Bran’s throat with the dagger meant to kill him in the first season, which he then hands to her in the seventh? How poetic to be killed by the knife meant to slit your throat years earlier, by the person who you’ve given the knife to, because you knew she’d be the only one strong enough to kill you?

Bran is the Night King, and Arya will have to kill him in his crippled form to kill the Night King.
